@_marinasulima  @genderfail  Marinasulima.nl

What does it mean to fight for liberation as part of a movement that is itself fractured by differences? How do we build solidarity in communities where power and privilege are unevenly distributed, even among those who are marginalized? Who is included in our visions of liberation, and who is left behind? These are some of the questions I kept returning to throughout my PhD in social psychology.

I'm Bao-Thi Van Cong, and my research focuses on intersectional solidarity within queer and trans communities. More specifically, I examine how racialization affects experiences of inclusion in queer and trans communities and how this shapes ideas of solidarity and collective organizing.

In today's stories, I share some key insights from my thesis and reflect on the messy research process that allowed for these findings to come to life.

Thank you so much to @_marinasulima for the beautiful artwork throughout my thesis, this post, and the stories and to @genderfail who make groovy fonts based on protest signs from queer and trans projects.

If you have any questions about the research (findings or process), feel free to contact me: btvc@psy.ku.dk
